The effects of alkali metal ions on the physiochemical and catalytic properties of Pd/NiAlOx catalysts for lean methane oxidation Cunshuo Li Conceptualization Methodology Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Investigation a + Songquan Tang Writing – original draft Investigation a + Bingyue Tang Investigation a Wenzhi Li Conceptualization Methodology Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a b ⁎ Liang Yuan Funding acquisition c a Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China aDepartment of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China b Institute of Energy, Hefei Comprehensive National Science Center, Hefei 230031, China Institute of Energy Hefei Comprehensive National Science Center Hefei 230031 China bInstitute of Energy, Hefei Comprehensive National Science Center, Hefei 230031, China c National & Local Joint Engineering Research Center of Precision Coal Mining, Anhui University of Science and Technology, Huainan 232001, China National & Local Joint Engineering Research Center of Precision Coal Mining Anhui University of Science and Technology Huainan 232001 China cNational & Local Joint Engineering Research Center of Precision Coal Mining, Anhui University of Science and Technology, Huainan 232001, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China. Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China + These authors contributed equally to this work. Self-assembled nickel-aluminum mixed oxides (NiAlOx) were prepared by using alkali metal ions as modifiers in a hydrothermal system and employed as the support materials for palladium catalysts. Via tuning the preparation procedure, both the ‘bonded’ and ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions were introduced to the NiAlOx materials for elucidating their effects on the physiochemical and the catalytic properties of Pd/NiAlOx catalysts for lean methane oxidation. Benefiting from the well-dispersed palladium nanoparticles, optimized electronic state of palladium phases, and the favorable structure of host materials, the optimal Pd/NiAl-Na sample exhibited excellent catalytic performance for methane oxidation. Over this sample, complete methane conversion was realized at 401 °C in the presence of 15 vol % water vapor, which was 26 °C lower than that of the Pd/NiAl catalyst (427 °C) at same reaction conditions. Due to the relatively small size of Li+ ions, certain amounts of Li+ incorporated into the NiAlOx lattice and improved the redox properties of NiAl-Li. However, its supported palladium catalysts did not show improved performance in the oxidation of methane. Furthermore, systematic characterizations revealed that the ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions resulted in the agglomeration of palladium nanoparticles and the formation of electron-deficient palladium component, thus exerting negative effect on the activities of palladium phases. It was hoped that this work could provide some fundamental understandings on the roles of alkali metal played in catalytic reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Alkali metal ions Pd/NiAlOx catalysts Lean methane oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Palladium-based catalysts are well acknowledged as one of the most efficient materials for emission-based catalytic control, especially for the elimination of lean methane in the exhaust of natural gas vehicles (NGVs) [1–12]. Among the developed materials, alumina-supported palladium nanoparticles have shown great promise due to their excellent activity, and many foundational works have been done based on this benchmark catalyst system [13–19]. However, Pd/Al2O3 catalysts generally suffer activity deterioration during the long-term operation, especially when water vapor is included in the reactant atmosphere [20]. The phase transformation of γ-alumina to α-alumina, which will occur under harsh reaction conditions, also limits their application to some extent [21]. One of the attempts to prepare thermally stable Pd/Al2O3 catalysts was reported by Yang and coworkers in 2019. Using potassium sulfate as a modifier in the hydrothermal system, they successfully synthesized a nanosheet-assembled Al2O3 (NA-Al2O3) material that have a desired BET surface area. More importantly, due to its abundance of penta-coordinated Al3+ and unique structural advantages for heterogeneous reactions, palladium phases were highly dispersed and thermally stabilized by this material, thus exhibiting excellent performance and stability in the catalytic combustion of methane (CCM) [22]. In addition, some structure stabilizers such as Mg [23,24], Co [25,26], and Ni [27,28] were also screened by researchers to improve the thermal stability of alumina-supported palladium materials, since these elements would favor the formation of alumina-based spinel structure that was much more stable than the transit alumina [27,28]. Regretfully, the microstructures of these host materials in above advances were not that favorable like the NA-Al2O3 material, which somewhat limited the maximization of palladium's reactivity. Besides tuning the properties of support materials, the catalytic activity of palladium species can be optimized by adding promoters [29], such as alkali metal cations. For example, Luo et al. reported that the alkali metal cations introduced during the deposition-precipitation of palladium precursors could not only well disperse palladium on the H-ZSM-5, but also acted as an electron-donating component to manipulate the electronic structure of the obtained Pd/H-ZSM-5-Me (Me = Li, Na, K, and Cs) catalyst, thus promoting the activation efficiency of methane molecules. The promotion effects of alkali metal ions enhanced with the increase of its ionic radius, following the order of K > Na > Li [30]. Very recently, Li's group also reported an alkali ion-promoted Pd subnanoclusters supported on defective γ-Al2O3 nanosheets. Similar to the roles of alkali metal ions in the Pd/H-ZSM-5-Me system, the introduction of Na+ effectively retarded the diffusion and migration of palladium atoms when tested under harsh conditions, and endowed the palladium phase with modified electronic character favorable for the oxidation of benzene [31]. More interestingly, suitable addition of Na could also decrease the contents of adsorbed water species while improving the mobility of oxygen species, thus contributing to the promoted water-resistance and performance of Na1Pd1/Al2O3 in the catalytic oxidation of benzene [32]. Thanks to the promotion effect of Na on the dispersion and surface electronic structures of palladium, another PdNa(0.6)/TiO2 catalyst also achieved higher H2 conversion rate and H2O2 selectivity in the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (DSHP) reaction [33]. Inspired by these reviewed works, here we envisaged that nanosheet-assembled aluminum-based mixed oxides (MAlOx) with high surface area could be prepared by Yang and coworkers’ methods [22]. Since only K+ was reported to be capable of optimizing the microstructure of alumina-based materials, the effectiveness of Li+ and Na+ should be evaluated as well. More importantly, alkali metal ions could be introduced to the final MAlOx materials simultaneously if the preparation procedures were delicately controlled. Accordingly, nanosheet-assembled MAlOx materials with abundant alkali metal ions on their surface might further serve as the supports for palladium catalysts, which could endow their supported palladium phases with excellent performance, stability, and water-resistance in the CCM reaction. Therefore, in this work, self-assembled metal-aluminum mixed oxides (especially NiAlOx) were synthesized in a hydrothermal system by using alkali metal ions as modifiers. Via tuning the preparation procedures of these materials, self-assembled NiAlOx with abundant alkali metal ions on their surface were also successfully prepared. Palladium phases supported on these materials were then employed as the catalysts for the CCM reaction. Based on the systematic characterization of corresponding materials, the effects of the ‘bonded’ and the ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions on the physiochemical properties of NiAlOx materials and the catalytic performance of palladium catalysts were comprehensively elucidated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of nickel-aluminum mixed oxides 2.1.1 Preparation of self-assembled NiAlOx materials The preparation of self-assembled NiAlOx was conducted according to the introduced method with slight modifications [22]. Typically, 2.000 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O, 0.776 g Ni(NO3)3·6H2O, 0.961 g of CO(NH2)2 along with different weights of alkali metal sulfate (0.440 g of Li2SO4, 0.568 g of Na2SO4, 0.697 g of K2SO4, respectively) were first dissolved in 80 mL deionized water. After stirring for 10 mins, the obtained solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 12 h. When cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with deionized water for three times. The resulting precipitate was dried at 80 °C for 12 h and finally calcined at 500 °C for 2 h. The final products were denoted as NiAl-Li, NiAl-Na, NiAl-K in the present manuscript. Because the precursors of these three materials were washed sufficiently before calcination, alkali metal ions detected in these samples were recognized as the ‘bonded’ alkali metal species. 2.1.2 Preparation of pure FeAlOx, CoAlOx, and NiAlOx materials The preparation of the pure NiAlOx materials without the modification of alkali metal ions was the same as that of NiAl-Li (Na, K), except that alkali metal ions were not introduced into the hydrothermal system. As references, FeAlOx and CoAlOx materials were also prepared using the same method to study the homogeneity of different elements in these two materials. 2.1.3 Preparation of NiAlOx materials with alkali metal ions The designed NiAlOx supports with certain amounts of alkali metal ions on their surface were also prepared in the same way as above, but their precursors were not washed with deionized water during centrifugation. The resulting products were denoted as NiAl-Li-Unwashed, NiAl-Na-Unwashed, NiAl-K-Unwashed, and they were prepared to study the roles played by the ‘deposited’ alkali metal species. It is noteworthy that the precursors of MAlOx (M = Fe, Co, Ni) materials were elaborately calcined at a relatively low temperature (500 °C) for studying the homogeneity of transition metal elements and aluminum, since homogeneous spinel structures would be formed at temperatures higher than 800 °C according to published literatures [27,28]. 2.2 Deposition of palladium species on nickel-aluminum mixed oxides The deposition of palladium species on support materials was carried out based on an ammonia evaporation (AE) method [34,35]. Specifically, 1.25 mL of 25–28% ammonia was added to 12.5 mL of Pd(NO3)2·2H2O solution (1 mg/mL) and then stirred for 0.5 h to form a solution with a pH of ca. 11. Once 0.5 g catalyst support was added, the suspension was sealed by parafilm and stirred overnight. To avoid the loss of palladium, the solvent was evaporated at 90 °C and the dried precursor was finally calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to obtain the supported palladium catalysts. 2.3 Catalyst characterization and activity measurement The physicochemical properties of representative samples were characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) elemental analysis, N2-physisorption experiments, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and oxygen-temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD). Details on the characterization and activity measurement were described in Supplementary Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The microstructural properties of nickel-alumina mixed oxides Our preliminary experiments have demonstrated that Co and Fe could not uniformly mix with Al since bulk Co3O4 and Fe2O3 were clearly observed in their SEM images (Fig. S1). Their XRD patterns (Fig. S2A), in which the diffractions of Co3O4 and Fe2O3 were well-intensified, also confirmed the formation of their bulk oxides. The reduction peak characteristic of these two oxides were also presented in their H2-TPR profiles (Fig. S2B). Therefore, NiAlOx oxides that possessed more homogeneous composition (vide infra) were selected for further investigations. The SEM and TEM images of NiAlOx samples were first taken to verify the effectiveness of alkali-metal cations on manipulating their microstructures, see Fig. 1 . For the NiAl sample, its lamellar structure shown in Fig. 1A–D was expected when considering that it was derived from layered double hydroxides (LDH) precursors [36,37]. Under the modification of alkali metal cations, the sizes of NiAlOx sheets decreased and these sheets began to be assembled. Obviously, the degree of assembly increased with the radius of the alkali metal cations (Fig. 1E–P), as excellent spherical structure with hollow interiors was formed when Na+ and K+ were selected as modifiers. Here we speculated that alkali metal cations might have intercalated between the layered precursors during the hydrothermal process [38,39]. The intercalated cations made the lamellar structure distorted or even broken, and thus decreased the size of these sheets. Driven by surface energy minimization, these fragments further assembled and thus formed the spherical structure. Moreover, although the nickel-aluminum precursors were elaborately calcined at relatively low temperature (500°C) that could not produce spinel structure, the STEM-EDS elemental mappings of the NiAl-Li, NiAl-Na, and NiAl-K samples still confirmed the homogeneous inclusions of nickel and aluminum (Fig. 2 B–D). As a contrast, although the signals of nickel and aluminum overlapped in most areas of its STEM-EDS elemental mapping image (Fig. 2A), a nanosheet composed mainly of alumina was still observed in the NiAl sample (marked with square boxes). Therefore, it seemed that the introduction of alkali metal cations actually improved the homogeneity of nickel and aluminum. Corresponding to the evolution of their microstructures, the results of N2-sorption experiment (Fig. 3 A) and the calculated parameters (Fig. 3B and Table 1 ) of these samples revealed that the BET surface areas of the NiAlOx materials increased from 164.4 (NiAl) to 171.3 (NiAl-Li), 196.6 (NiAl-Na) and 187.4 (NiAl-K) m2/g with the modification of alkali metal cations, and its pore volume almost doubled with their assembly. To our knowledge, the surface areas of the self-assembled NiAlOx samples were larger than most of the reported MAlOx materials [23–28], which allowed us to expect their potential as the support materials for palladium catalysts. 3.2 The composition of nickel-alumina mixed oxides The XRD patterns of these samples along with that of γ-Al2O3 were plotted in Fig. 3C to further confirm their compositions and crystallinities. By comparison with the diffractions of γ-Al2O3, it was found that all the four NiAlOx samples were actually the mixture of NiO and γ-Al2O3. Such a composition was expected since the spinel would not form during the calcination process. As the intensities of Co3O4 and Fe2O3 were much stronger than Al2O3 in Fig. S2A, the diffractions of NiO and Al2O3 were comparable in these cases, and the diffraction intensities of NiAl-Na and NiAl-K were visibly weaker than those of NiAl and NiAl-Li samples, indicating the decrease in their long-range order. Moreover, as will be discussed below, NiO and Al2O3 phases were not simply physically mixed but interacting with each other in our NiAlOx materials, since their reduction behaviors were different from that of bulk NiO. Their composition information obtained from the XPS results (Table 1) demonstrated that the Ni/Al ratio of the four samples were lower than their theoretical value (0.5), and the values of (Ni + Al)/O were close to 1.0. Therefore, a theoretical formula of NiAl7O8 was determined for our prepared NiAlOx materials. More interestingly, certain amounts of Li atoms (1.10 atom %) were detected in the XPS spectrum of the NiAl-Li sample while only trace of Na (0.15 atom %) and K (0.06 atom %) were detected in the latter two samples. To provide more information on the composition of these materials, their Raman spectra were also recorded and shown in Fig. 3D. As γ-Al2O3 was Raman-inactive, the spectra of NiAlOx samples were dominated by the vibration of NiO at ca. 550 cm−1. However, the Raman peak of NiAl-Li shifted to higher wavenumber (551 cm−1) when compared with those of other samples (547 cm−1 for NiAl and NiAl-Li, and 546 cm−1 for NiAl-K). Considering that the ionic radius of Li+ (0.72 Å) was quite close to that of Ni2+ (0.69 Å) [40], it was deduced that Li+ might have incorporated into the lattice of NiAlOx and thus resulted in such a migration. This deduction was then supported by the results of their H2-TPR experiments (Fig. 3E), since the reduction of NiAl-Li occurred at much lower temperatures than other three samples, which was the typical character of doped/unstable materials. It must be emphasized that the reduction of all the NiAlOx materials took place at temperatures higher than 400°C, which was much higher than that of bulk NiO [41,42], elucidating that the nickel element was interacting with aluminum other than simply forming bulk NiO. To confirm the incorporation of Li+, the EPR spectra of four samples were also recorded in Fig. 3F. While other samples were EPR-silent, the spectrum of NiAl-Li gave weak signal at the g value range of 1.93–2.10, indicating that Li+ did mix into the lattice of NiAlOx and thus result in the formation of lone electrons. In summary, the results of XRD diffractions, Raman spectra, H2-TPR experiments, and EPR spectra confirmed the composition and homogeneity of our NiAlOx materials, and the excellent redox properties of NiAl-Li was revealed as well. 3.3 The catalytic performance of the palladium catalysts supported on nickel-aluminum mixed oxides Motivated by above discussions, we then deposited 1.0 wt% palladium on the four NiAlOx materials and then tested their activities for lean methane oxidation. As shown in Fig. 4 A, the light-off curves of palladium catalysts first revealed the similar activity of the Pd/NiAl, Pd/NiAl-Na, and Pd/NiAl-K catalysts. Unexpectedly, the Pd/NiAl-Li catalyst only exhibited much poorer activity towards the CCM reaction instead. The complete oxidation of lean methane was realized below 425 °C over the first three catalysts, but was not achievable even at 500 °C over Pd/NiAl-Li. Considering that Li+ have been proved to incorporate into the lattice of the NiAl-Li sample, such performance data demonstrated that the Li+ actually have negative effect on the catalytic activity of palladium towards the CCM reaction. The performance evaluation of the four support materials (Fig. S3A) also presented similar trend, since the NiAl-Li material possessing better redox capacity showed worse activity as well. It was also noticed that there was a performance gap between the light-off curves of bare NiAl-Na (K) and that of NiAl, although their supported palladium catalysts delivered close methane conversion in the whole temperature range. Therefore, to further clarify the roles of alkali metals, designed support materials, NiAl-Li-Unwashed, NiAl-Na-Unwashed, and NiAl-K-Unwashed were then prepared and employed as the carriers for palladium phases. The atomic contents of alkali metal in these support materials (Table 1) were 1.34, 1.41, and 1.62 atom %, respectively, suggesting that certain amounts of alkali metal ions have been deposited on the surface of the three samples. The catalytic performance of their supported palladium catalysts were shown in Fig. 4B. Different from our expectation, the presence of Na+ and K+ significantly shifted the light-off curves to higher temperature range, and the detrimental effect of the K+ seemed to be stronger than that of Na+. It was also noteworthy that, while the content of Li in NiAl-Li-Unwashed did not show obvious increase when compared with that of NiAl-Li, the catalytic performance of Pd/NiAl-Li-Unwashed was also close to that of Pd/NiAl-Li. Relationships between the contents of alkali metal ions and the catalytic performance of corresponding samples revealed that alkali metal cations intrinsically hindered the efficient activation of methane molecules on active palladium sites. Given that Na+ was reported to be favorable for the activation of benzene on palladium sites [31,32], these observations implied that the activation mechanism of methane and benzene would be electronically different. For further evaluating the potential of our optimal catalysts (Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K) in practical application, we then tested their water resistance and plotted their light-off curves in Fig. 4C. With the introduction of water vapor, a performance gap between the light-off curve of Pd/NiAl and those of Pd/NiAl-Na (K) appeared, and the performance of Pd/NiAl-Na was slightly higher than Pd/NiAl-K. Such results implied that the mass and heat transfer might have limited the efficient oxidation of methane over the Pd/NiAl sample under harsh reaction conditions, but the favorable structure of assembled NiAlOx materials effectively accelerated the reaction rate under same conditions. Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K also exhibited excellent thermal and stability at both 300 and 500 °C (Fig. S4) within 50 h. More importantly, the methane conversion kept 100% at 500 °C in the presence of water vapor, see Fig. 4D. The exceptional hydrothermal stability of Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K was better than most of catalyst materials we have ever reported [43–46], and thus, these two samples represented attractive candidates for practical applications. 3.4 The physicochemical properties of palladium catalysts supported on washed nickel-aluminum mixed oxides To comprehensively elucidate the effects of ‘bonded’ alkali metal ions on the physiochemical properties of NiAlOx supports and active phases, the palladium catalysts supported on the washed nickel-aluminum mixed oxides were studied by the following characterizations. Based on the existing discussions, it was noted that only Li+ ions might have bonded with the NiAlOx materials. 3.4.1 The composition and redox properties of palladium catalysts Identical with those of their support materials, the XRD patterns of palladium catalysts (Fig. 5 A) also showed progressively weaker diffractions under the modification of alkali metal ions. The signal of PdO (101) at 34° was not distinguishable due to the interference of the merged diffractions of NiO and Al2O3 ranging from 30 to 40°. However, it could not be excluded that the size of palladium was too small to be detected by the XRD technique considering the relatively low palladium content in our catalyst system. To probe the states of palladium, the Raman spectra of the palladium catalysts, which were sensitive to the vibrations of metal-oxygen bonds, were also obtained and shown in Fig. 5B. With the deposition of palladium, a signal at ∼ 645 cm−1 characteristic of PdO [47] appeared in the Raman spectra of the Pd/NiAl and Pd/NiAl-K samples but was absent in those of the Pd/NiAl-Li and Pd/NiAL-Na. This meant that weaker palladium-related signals were excited from the area of the laser spot in the latter two samples, suggesting the more uniform dispersion of palladium in the Pd/NiAl-Li and Pd/NiAL-Na samples. Indeed, as will be discussed below, the Pd/NiAl sample did show palladium nanoparticles larger than those of other three counterparts in its TEM images. In addition, the deposition of palladium slightly altered the H2-TPR profiles of their support materials, see Fig. 5C. Within our expectation, the reducibility of the Pd/NiAl-Li catalyst was still the best, as the location of its reduction peak appeared earlier than other samples. Consistent with the H2-TPR experiments, the O2-TPD profiles of palladium catalysts plotted in Fig. 5D also indicated the excellent redox ability of the Pd/NiAl-Li sample. Specifically, except for the profile of Pd/NiAl-Li, in which two visible peaks centered at ca. 175 and 600 °C were presented, other samples did not show obvious TCD signals during the whole temperature range. According to the published literatures, the first peak (at 175 °C) in the profile of Pd/NiAl-Li accounted for chemisorbed oxygen species that have been proved to be beneficial for catalytic oxidation reaction [44,48]. In other words, the temperature-programmed experiments demonstrated that oxygen molecules could be activated more efficiently on the Pd/NiAl-Li sample. However, since the rate-determining step of methane oxidation was accepted to be the breakage of the first C-H bond of methane molecule, the states of primary active phase (palladium) should be more important indicators affecting the activity of our catalysts. 3.4.2 The particle sizes and electronic states of palladium phases It has been well recognized that the catalytic performance of palladium closely correlates with its particle sizes [13,49] and electronic structures [50,51]. Therefore, we studied these two properties of our palladium catalysts via the TEM and XPS techniques, respectively. Fig. 6 displayed the TEM images of palladium catalysts taken at different magnifications, which allowed the detailed inspection of their morphologies and the sizes of palladium particles. At relatively low magnifications (the first column of Fig. 6), the progressively assembled morphologies of the four samples were visualized again, indicating that the deposition of palladium and subsequent calcination did not destroy the microstructure of support materials. At higher magnifications (the second column of Fig. 6), some black spots accounted for palladium nanoparticles appeared in these images because of the larger atomic number of Pd. Although palladium nanoparticles on the NiAl material were slightly larger (Fig. 6B), the particle sizes of palladium on other three samples were estimated to be smaller than 2 nm. Taking account palladium nanoparticles with small sizes were responsible for the efficient oxidation of methane at low temperatures, such results actually rationalized the better performance of Pd/NiAl-Na (K) than Pd/NiAl at wet conditions. However, as palladium particles also uniformly dispersed in the image of Pd/NiAl-Li (Fig. 6D), the effect of incorporated Li+ species on the electronic structures of related elements should be investigated as well for understanding its deteriorated performance. Consequently, the electronic structures of all the elements included in our catalyst system were studied by their XPS results (Fig. 7 ). For the results of Al 2p photoelectron spectra (Fig. 7A), electrons were mainly excited at binding energy (B.E.) of ∼ 74.0 eV in those of Pd/NiAl, Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K, but that of Pd/NiAl-Li appeared at higher B.E. value, 74.9 eV, proving the incorporation of Li+ from the electronic view. The O 1s spectra that consisted of two components, the lattice oxygen (∼ 530.7 eV) and alumina-related hydroxyl species (∼ 532.0 eV), also showed similar offset in Fig. 7B, and the half width of O 1s peak was smaller in the Pd/NiAl-Li sample. Because of the doping of Li+, more Ni3+ species, which were associated with the XPS signal at ∼ 856.4 eV in the Ni 2p3/2 spectra (Fig. 7C), were formed in Pd/NiAl-Li for charge balance. Although palladium was considered as the main active phase for methane oxidation in the Pd/NiAlOx catalyst system, nickel species actually contributed to the activation of methane as well. As displayed in Fig. S3A, all the bare NiAlOx materials exhibited moderate activities for the CCM reaction, and the complete conversion of methane were even realized at 600°C over NiAl-Na and NiAl-K. However, the bare NiAl-Li sample performed much worse under same conditions, indicating that the increased content of Ni3+ species in this sample was intrinsically detrimental to the oxidation of methane. For the Pd 3d spectra, the deconvoluted Pd 3d spectra shown in Fig. 7D revealed that the palladium species of all the four samples were predominated in an oxidation state of +2, and another palladium component located at ca. 339.0 eV was also visible in their spectra. The position of the latter palladium component was higher than Pd4+ species but lower than the satellite peak of Pd 3d5/2, which made the accurate ascription of this component difficult. Taking the existed performance data and published literature that ascribed the Pd4+ species to the key phase for lowering the activation barrier of methane molecules into account [51], this palladium species actually played minor role in the oxidation of methane and, it should be the satellite palladium species. Notably, the concentration of this phase was larger in the Pd 3d spectra of Pd/NiAl and Pd/NiAl-Li than those in other samples. It was also discovered that the introduction of Li+ shifted the binding energy of palladium to higher value, implying that the palladium species in Pd/NiAl-Li were more electron-deficient. Since the electron-deficient palladium species would be proved to be intrinsically detrimental to the activity of palladium phase in the next section, such an observation actually provided another explanation for the worse reactivity of this sample. Overall, the systematic studies on the palladium catalysts supported on the washed NiAlOx materials revealed that (1) the palladium particles supported on the NiAl support were larger than those on other supports, and they included higher contents of minor palladium phase than its counterparts. (2) The incorporation of Li+ into the NiAlOx lattice was further proved. Although palladium phase was uniformly dispersed on the surface of NiAl-Li, these Li+ cations increased the contents of Ni3+ species and shifted the binding energy of palladium species to higher value, which might be the main reasons for its deteriorated performance. (3) Due to their relatively large ionic radius, Na+ (1.02 Å) and K+ (1.38 Å) [52] could not incorporate into the lattice of NiAlOx and thus did not change the composition of nickel element significantly. The well-dispersed palladium nanoparticles, the optimal electronic states of palladium species, along with the hierarchical structures of their support materials, might have contributed to the excellent performance and water resistance of the Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K catalysts. 3.5 The physicochemical properties of palladium catalysts supported on unwashed nickel-aluminum mixed oxides As envisaged in the introduction, the NiAlOx materials with abundant alkali metal ions were also prepared by omitting the washing procedure during the centrifugation process. Regretfully, their supported palladium catalysts did not show improved activity in the CCM reaction, and instead, their performance deteriorated significantly with the introduction of more ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions. To investigate the intrinsic reasons for the observed phenomena, the physicochemical properties of palladium catalysts supported on the unwashed NiAlOx materials were then studied. 3.5.1 The composition and redox properties of palladium catalysts The composition of these samples were also confirmed by their XRD patterns and Raman spectra. Although the diffractions of Al2O3 more distinguishable in the palladium catalysts supported on the washed NiAlOx materials (Fig. 8 A), their composition were not significantly altered by the deposited alkali metal species. Accordingly, the Raman signal of NiO in Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K (Fig. 8B) did not show visible migration when compared with their washed counterparts, see Fig. 5B, suggesting that the deposited Na+ and K+ could not incorporate into the lattice of nickel-aluminum mixed oxides due to their larger ionic radius. Moreover, the Raman signal of palladium, which was absent in the spectra of Pd/NiAl-Li and Pd/NiAl-Na, became appreciable in all the three samples, especially in the latter two samples. Since alkali metals have been proved to be effective in stabilizing palladium nanoparticles and preventing their sintering [30,31], this observation was unexpected and warranted further investigations. Interestingly, in Fig. 8C, the redox ability of the latter two samples reflected by the H2-TPR experiments became better when considerable amounts of alkali metals ions were introduced into the catalyst system. This result, together with the H2-TPR results shown in Figs. 5C and 3E, finally exemplified the weak correlation between the redox ability reflected by H2-TPR and the catalytic performance in our catalyst system. In contrast to the locking effect of K+ on the oxygen species in Co3O4 reported in the literature [53], it seemed that the deposited alkali metal ions slightly improved the oxygen mobility of catalysts instead, as small nascent desorption peaks appeared in the O2-TPD profiles of the three samples (Fig. 8D). 3.5.2 The particle sizes and electronic states of palladium phases As the redox ability reflected by the H2-TPR and O2-TPD became better with the introduction of alkali metal ions instead, the reasons for the deteriorated performance of palladium catalysts supported on unwashed NiAlOx materials thus remained elusive. Therefore, the TEM images of these samples (Fig. 9 ) were also taken to provide information on the dispersion states of palladium nanoparticles. With the deposition of alkali metal ions, the palladium particles became visible in their TEM images, and they were observed even in the low-magnification TEM images of Pd/NiAl-Li-unwashed (Fig. 9A). Based on the images taken at higher magnifications (Fig. 9B, D and F), the average particle sizes of palladium were determined to be 4.0, 4.5, and 4.1 nm in Pd/NiAl-Li, Pd/NiAl-Na, and Pd/NiAl-K, respectively. Such an observation supported the Raman results shown in Fig. 8C, but was contrary to the reported conclusions reviewed in the introduction, suggesting that the roles of alkali metal differed in various catalyst systems. Here we proposed that the deposited alkali metal ions might weaken the adhesion strength of palladium at the palladium-NiAlOx interface and/or decrease the average escape energy of individual palladium atom from palladium nanoparticles, thus favored the agglomeration of palladium species. Since palladium particles possessing relatively small sizes were responsible for the ignition of methane molecules at low temperatures, the analysis of TEM images first provide an explanation for the poor activity of Pd/NiAlOx-Unwashed catalysts. The electronic structures of these samples were then studied by their XPS spectra shown in Fig. 10 . While the Al 2p (Fig. 10A) and O 1s (Fig. 10B) spectra of these samples were quite similar, Ni3+ species located at higher B.E. values occupied larger concentration in the Ni 2p3/2 spectra of Pd/NiAl-Li-unwashed and Pd/NiAl-Na-unwashed (Fig. 10C). Considering that more Ni3+ species in the Pd/NiAl-Li have been proved in Fig. 7C, the result of the Pd/NiAl-Li-unwashed was within our expectation. Interestingly, similar variation found in the Pd/NiAl-Na-unwashed sample indicated that certain amounts of Na+ might have interacted with the NiAlOx oxides during the calcination process and thus altered its electronic structure as well. On the other hand, possibly due to the largest size of potassium cations, the composition of nickel element in the Pd/NiAl-K-Unwashed sample was not changed significantly. The effects of increased contents of alkali metal ions on the catalytic performance of NiAl-Unwashed were also studied based on the light-off curves shown in Fig. S3B. Like the NiAl-Li sample, the performance of NiAl-Na-Unwashed became worse with the increase of Ni3+ species. However, although more Ni3+ were not detected in the NiAl-K-Unwashed sample, its performance deteriorated as well. Hence the deposited K+ species might also slow down the transformation or desorption of the intermediates or final products in the CCM reaction. For the electronic states of palladium phase (Fig. 10D), it was found that the deposition of alkali metal ions mainly shifted the binding energies of palladium species to higher values (ca. 337.1 eV), and more components at higher B.E. were detected in all the three samples. That is, the deposited alkali metal ions actually acted as electron accepters in our catalyst system. Based on quantitative analysis, the ratios of Pdsat/Pd(II) increased from 0.25 for Pd/NiAl-Li to 0.26 for Pd/NiAl-Na and 0.31 for Pd/NiAl-K, identical with the worsening performance of the three samples. These important variations and the performance data of corresponding samples demonstrated that the electron-deficient palladium species were not that effective on the activation of methane than palladium species possessing lower oxidation state. Therefore, the presence of more electron-deficient palladium components further rationalized the deteriorated performance of Pd/NiAlOx-Unwashed from the electronic view. In short, the results of investigations of palladium catalysts supported on the unwashed NiAlOx supports elucidated that (1) all of the three deposited alkali metal ions resulted in the agglomeration of palladium particles and increased the B.E. values of palladium species. These two effects mainly explained the poor activities of palladium catalysts supported on unwashed NiAlOx materials. (2) The deposited Na+ species might interact with the NiAlOx support during the calcination process and thus change the electronic structures of nickel element, but similar role was not observed for the deposited K+ species. 4 Conclusion Herein, different types of alkali metal ions were introduced to the NiAlOx system, and they were proved to exert different influences on the physiochemical properties of both the support materials and active palladium phases. Li+ ions incorporated into the lattice of NiAlOx, endowing the resulting materials with excellent redox abilities and affecting the electronic states of palladium and nickel species. However, the derived effects of the bonded Li+ were negative to the catalytic performance of its supported palladium catalyst. The ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions, which leaded to the agglomeration of palladium nanoparticles and the formation of inactive palladium species with higher B.E. values, was intrinsically detrimental to the efficient oxidation of methane. More specifically, while the roles of deposited Li+ were similar to those of bonded Li+, the deposited Na+ interacted with the NiAlOx materials during the calcination process, thus increasing the contents of Ni3+ that was ineffective in the oxidation of methane. In addition to the common effect of deposited alkali metal ions, the deposited K+ did not significantly alter the physiochemical properties of NiAlOx and supported palladium phases. The optimal catalysts in the present work were Pd/NiAl-Na and Pd/NiAl-K with trace of alkali metal detected, which exhibited excellent performance, stability and water-resistance in the CCM reaction. On the other hand, it should be emphasized that, although the Pd/NiAlOx-Unwashed catalysts did not show expected activity in the oxidation of lean methane, they might exhibit desired catalytic properties in other catalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: Self-assembled nickel-aluminum mixed oxides (NiAlOx) were prepared by using alkali metal ions as modifiers in a hydrothermal system and employed as the support materials for palladium catalysts. Via tuning the preparation procedure, both the ‘bonded’ and ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions were introduced to the NiAlOx materials for elucidating their effects on the physiochemical and the catalytic properties of Pd/NiAlOx catalysts for lean methane oxidation. Benefiting from the well-dispersed palladium nanoparticles, optimized electronic state of palladium phases, and the favorable structure of host materials, the optimal Pd/NiAl-Na sample exhibited excellent catalytic performance for methane oxidation. Over this sample, complete methane conversion was realized at 401 °C in the presence of 15 vol % water vapor, which was 26 °C lower than that of the Pd/NiAl catalyst (427 °C) at same reaction conditions. Due to the relatively small size of Li+ ions, certain amounts of Li+ incorporated into the NiAlOx lattice and improved the redox properties of NiAl-Li. However, its supported palladium catalysts did not show improved performance in the oxidation of methane. Furthermore, systematic characterizations revealed that the ‘deposited’ alkali metal ions resulted in the agglomeration of palladium nanoparticles and the formation of electron-deficient palladium component, thus exerting negative effect on the activities of palladium phases. It was hoped that this work could provide some fundamental understandings on the roles of alkali metal played in catalytic reaction.
coredata.dc:title: The effects of alkali metal ions on the physiochemical and catalytic properties of Pd/NiAlOx catalysts for lean methane oxidation
